title: Equipotential Lines of 5 Point Sources in Ring

content.question:
Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A combination of point charges produces the electric equipotential lines shown on the diagram above. The difference between successive equipotential lines is <math alttext="25 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown on the figure.

(a) Without making any calculations, describe the process by which a student could calculate the approximate electric field at point N without knowing the quantity of charge of each source charge.

frqParts.text:
Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A combination of point charges produces the electric equipotential lines shown on the diagram above. The difference between successive equipotential lines is <math alttext="25 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown on the figure.

(a) Without making any calculations, describe the process by which a student could calculate the approximate electric field at point N without knowing the quantity of charge of each source charge.

In terms of coordinate axes, describe the direction of the electric field at:
(b) Point R

(e) A test charge is placed at points R, S, or L. Rank the magnitude of the electrical potential energy of the system when the test charge is at these points from greatest to least. If any of the quantities are equal, clearly indicate this. Justify your ranking, citing relevant physics principles.

A test charge is moved between various locations along the paths X, Y, and Z indicated on the figure above.

(f) Rank the net work done on the test charge by the electric field as the test charge is moved along paths X, Y, and Z. If any of the quantities are equal, clearly indicate this. Justify your answer.
(g) What is the net work done by the electric field on the test charge as it travels along Path X to Path Y and then along Path Z? Justify your answer using appropriate physics principles.

(h) The cross-sections of two closed Gaussian surfaces are indicated on the figure above. The total electric flux for these surfaces is <math alttext="phi sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="phi sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. Compare the magnitude of electric flux passing through these surfaces. Justify your comparison by citing relevant physics principles. You may write “flux 1” to indicate <math alttext="phi sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and “flux 2” to indicate <math alttext="phi sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
